name: NPR
text:
Dr. Anthony Fauci says he has received death threats and his daughters have been harassed as a result of his high-profile statements about the coronavirus pandemic.
https://t.co/KwnaUQXth4

name: NPR
text:
Fair Wayne Bryant has spent nearly 23 years in prison for stealing a pair of hedge clippers.

He asked for a review of his life sentence for the crime.

The Louisiana Supreme Court denied the request.
https://t.co/UhJ6AEHQZZ

name: NPR
text: Virginia has rolled out a new app designed to alert users who may have been exposed to the coronavirus — becoming the first state to use contract-tracing technology developed by Google and Apple. https://t.co/8oxxDyB6KC

name: NPR
text:
BREAKING: Twitter temporarily blocked President Trump's election campaign account from tweeting until it removed a post containing COVID-19 falsehoods.
https://t.co/tXC5zC9Pbh

name: NPR
text:
Former Colombian President Álvaro Uribe has been placed on house arrest as the country's Supreme Court investigates whether he played a role in a scheme to bribe witnesses in a legal case involving ex-members of paramilitary death squads.
https://t.co/ZYlZDcNjEu

name: NPR
text: Since relocating to two bubbles in Edmonton and Toronto, Canada, the National Hockey League says it's given more than 7,000 tests to players on 24 teams — and none have come back positive for COVID-19.  https://t.co/6WwWOT2uHX

name: NPR
text:
Dr. Fauci: "I wouldn't have imagined in my wildest dreams that people who object to things that are pure public health principles are so set against it ... that they actually threaten you. I mean, that to me is just strange."
https://t.co/O2JgITxU72

name: NPR
text:
Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti announced that he is authorizing the city to shut off water and power service to properties that defy public health orders and host large house parties.
https://t.co/crdaVPazeK

name: NPR
text:
Job postings for entry-level positions fell by 73%, compared with before COVID-19 hit. And openings for internships are down 83%. 

For those in the class of 2020 who have actually landed jobs — it's often been a strange journey. 
https://t.co/3E52HslFoM

name: NPR
text:
North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper says the state will remain paused in Phase 2 of its reopening plan — keeping bars, gyms and indoor entertainment venues closed until at least Sept. 11.
https://t.co/zWL4l7mSfi

name: NPR
text:
Parks in low-income and nonwhite areas are half the size and almost 5 times more crowded than those in white areas, a new study finds.
https://t.co/b1KWu7A8Rl

name: NPR
text:
Beetles make up around 40% of all insect species and around 25% of all animals. 

Are there really that many different kinds of beetles — or do scientists have a strong pro-beetle bias?
https://t.co/UJG4bUtgzT

name: NPR
text:
When President Trump was interviewed by Axios journalist Jonathan Swan, the matter of coronavirus death rates in different countries was raised. 

These charts show how the U.S. ranks on both per capita and per case counts: https://t.co/qnwoXKY4W0

name: NPR
text:
Public health experts are concerned about people having both the flu and COVID-19 at the same time. "We don't know yet whether that could compound either illness," says Dr. Ashish Jha.
https://t.co/odv7sU8QgE

name: NPR
text:
Does it seem realistic to have a vaccine before the end of the year?

Dr. Paul Offit, an FDA adviser: "No, it doesn't. As it stands right now, the vaccines that we've been talking about, which are two-dose vaccines, those phase 3 trials ... just started."
https://t.co/AZPGIKHJtn

name: NPR
text:
Missouri voters approved creating a state constitutional amendment that would open Medicaid eligibility to include healthy adults. Researchers estimate the expansion would save the state some $39 million a year.
 https://t.co/khX0njLVXe

name: NPR
text:
Lauren Beukes' novel is set in the future where a virus has killed off most men, and one woman is racing to free her son from the government.

"I wanted to interrogate the preconceptions that a world of women would be kinder," Beukes says. 
https://t.co/yiXsbsXuYa

name: NPR
text:
Rapper @ChristylezBacon says the COVID-19 pandemic has hit his Southeast D.C. neighborhood hard.  

“Where I'm from, you're in a food desert. If you can't make the trek to the grocery store and get on the bus, it's a tough situation for sure." https://t.co/75aBiV7fHf

name: NPR
text: A 9-year-old boy was able to regain enough muscle strength to run with the help of gene therapy — a treatment that could change the lives of thousands of children with Duchenne muscular dystrophy. https://t.co/3LCKjl6QFU

name: NPR
text: India's prime minister laid the cornerstone of a Hindu temple that is being built on the ruins of a mosque destroyed by Hindu extremists — a gesture painful to Muslims, hundreds of whom died there. https://t.co/F9NclG2MLT
